children.text: Yesterday, the Senate voted to deny the nation‚Äôs railway workers seven paid sick days. How much would those sick days have cost rail companies? It‚Äôs likely far less than many would imagine, according to financial records reviewed in
Today at 5PM ET during our weekly Callin show,
, I will be discussing the Biden administration and Congress siding with railroad barons and selling out rail workers. I‚Äôll also be taking questions from the audience on the matter LIVE on-air.

Senators Help Donors Derail Paid Sick Days

children.text: The U.S. Senate voted Thursday to deny

rail workers a handful of paid sick days that would have cost the equivalent of just four days of recent profits made by senators‚Äô railroad industry donors, according to financial records reviewed by
The cost of paid sick days for this year ‚Äî roughly
‚Äî would be less than half the amount that a single railroad tycoon, Warren Buffett,
to his family foundations last week.

Buffett‚Äôs railroad firm BNSF scored a huge win when 43 senators blocked paid sick leave for exhausted railroad workers, and passed legislation preventing workers from striking. The Senate vote followed the Biden White House effectively pouring cold water on efforts to tie paid sick leave to the bill shutting down the rail strike,
that the president ‚Äúdoes not support any bill or amendment that will delay a bill that‚Äôs getting to his desk by Saturday.‚Äù
Rail workers were asking for the same amount of paid sick days that Biden in 2020
he would grant to all workers in America if he was elected president. Biden has not committed to signing an
requiring railroads and other government contractors to provide paid sick days.

children.text: While opposing a plan that would have required them to spend $321 million to give workers seven paid sick days, the main railroad companies raked in more than $7 billion in profits and paid out over $1.8 billion in dividends, in a year where they and their lobbying groups have spent more than $13 million lobbying Congress ‚Äî after railroad CEOs
more than $3.3 million in campaign contributions to Congress in the 2021-2022 cycle, according to data collected by Opensecrets.org.

The railroad workers ‚Äî constrained by an outdated labor law, the Railway Labor Act, which severely limits their right to strike ‚Äî have been outgunned this time by powerful corporate titans bearing little difference from the railroads‚Äô robber baron founders.

prepared by the Biden administration stated that the railroads contend that their enormous profits do not reflect ‚Äúany contributions by labor.‚Äù The railroads, meanwhile, have waged a full-court press to have Congress implement an agreement negotiated by the Biden administration that only includes
of paid sick leave, after refusing to agree to any paid sick days in three years of talks with unions.

in the last quarter. For the nine months ending on September 30, the company‚Äôs profits exploded to $4.5 billion ‚Äî a $172 million increase from the prior year‚Äôs haul. Buffett himself is worth an estimated $110 billion,
to Bloomberg. The press regularly fawns over the so-called ‚ÄúOracle of Omaha‚Äù for his supposed frugality, even though he travels in a
